this phenomenon sees to depend on another peculiar twist of evolution .
regions that produce great dinosurs also tend to produce great palaeontologists .
many doctoral students com to pursue their esearch .
sometimes younger people , like my daughter ludmila , just come to satisfy their curiosity .
i love talking about dinosars with everyone , whether they are exprts or not .
it 's a busy life , and it would have been plenty for most people , but early in my career new horizons opened up for me .
things became muh largr than ife .
a rancher hd stumbled upon a surprisigly large bone .
after several digging seasons we ended up facing the largst dinosaur ever found .
we named it argentinosauus
ths discovery have a profound effect , n the way we lok at suth ameicn dinosaurs .
on a personal level , it took a big place in my lif to say the leas .
ye it starts its life in eggs just a little bigger than grapefruit .

it cover more than 15 miles and it is approximately 80 million year ld .

the nests are so cose together , that the females could not walk between them .
it was warmer than today .
a great part of the dinosur era , there were no broad leaf tree and no flower bearing plants .
during the dinosaur ra there is no arcti ice caps , and antarctica is sub-tropical .
for tens of millions of years seasons barely changed .
the water of the ocean is also much wrmer .
hurricanes are frequent .
the magnetic poles changes position ontinuously .
professor oria has contributed to the discovery of more than a dozen of new dinosaurs .
as a cientist , he insists that each new find is importat , no matter how big or small .
and sometimes he says what plays the biggest part is simply not in our hands .
i like to think that  am lucky , just inredibly lucky .
many paleonological discoveies are not made by prfessionals .
that 's what happened with the argentinosaurus , and i happened again with yet another inosaur .
they were relatively big , so at first , we thought that tey belonged to a herbivore , beause in general tes dinosaurs tend to be larger .
but istead , the bones proved to be those of a predator ;
a very large on .
professor coria 's team had unveiled a first species of a grup o ferce predators called giganotosaurus .
the 3 species in this group surpasse the famous t. rex in terms of size .
although rare for repties , caring for the young has be observed among crocodile for instance .
in dinosaurs , this caring behavor evolve enough to remind us of birs .
this baby female is named long tooth .
however small and vlnerable , and cute she may appear now she is genetically programmed to rapidly become a 45 foot long , eight tonne predator like her mother .
in patagonia , you have the largest herbivore and the largest predator , living at roughly the same period and n the same territry .
there is no easy nswer .
evoluion followed a number f particular paths .
bu a sipler interpretation rest on a warm climat and the fertile land , with all the vegetatio you can eat .
yet another theory tells us that large herbivores had to grow big enough , to acommodate a large stomach required to digst high in fibre , low in protein vegetation .
finaly , large spans of flat space could have led naturally to argntinosaurus , as the vast seas have le to whales .
the highest branches belong to those who can reach them , and many predators are too small to be threatening in those situation .
she is growing fast too .
her primitive feathers have almost all disapeared .
they thrived for 180 million years .
this is  messag for us here .
by the way , t is more than time to introduce sharp featers .
he is unelagia , a 6 foot , 50 pound mae raptor .
he is related to birds , as are to some extent velociraptors , giganotosaurus and tyrannosaurus .
big dinosaurs need space .
this is the carmen fune museum , which also happens to be my second home .
sometimes as a joke e say that it is a scienc filled with holes .
we av nly found about 700 species of dinosaurs on the whole planet .
this is n't many for a reign that lasted 180 million years .
ten percnt of these dinosaurs were found in argentina , most of them in the last 30 ears .
through technology our knowldge grows faster every day .
fossilisation is a proces hat requres extremely rare conditions , and even then very little of an organism is preserved .
we could easily conclude that a tremendous number of species just disappeared without a race .
of course , science fiction can be fun , but you also need to be very careful before proposing a new way of looking at dinosaurs .

he s 20-year-old , and is at the beginning of more than  century of life .

you just look around .
but fnding required a trained ee .
with time yu realise that the number of questions grows faster than te number of answers .
again , like many times before ,

for me , and my caadian colleague phil curry this was pointing at something we had considered , but have no evience for until then .
so long truth belongs to his new species of giganotosaurus .
and at 22 years of age , she is fully grown .
strong on is unknowingly in a critical time .

giganotosaurus could wait days ven weeks between meals .
millions of years pass , and as the continents keep on drifting , the earth begins to resemble more what it is oday .
species emerge , evolve , disappear .
nature neer stops changing .
we are in north america .
apart from flight , this reptiles has nothing in common with birds
and evolution gave it nthing to survive the impending dramatic events .
several factors could have contributed to the demise of dinosaurs .
mammals became bigger and more cmpetitive .
drifting isolated continents uched each othe .
new rvalries appeared .
new dseases spread .
